heading: free now means free on geocities
subheading: satisfied that geocities has fully backed down from its claim to users' content, organizers call off a boycott against geocities and its owner yahoo. by declan mccullagh.
author: declan mccullagh
text: organizers of a yahoo boycott have called it quits, saying they're satisfied the company has abandoned its claim to owning the web pages of the site's geocities members. yahoo this week revised its terms of service for a second time to appease customers whom rival services had begun to lure away.see also: sites lure geocities refugees- - - - - -the new agreement applies only to geocities members and states that yahoo will only use text, images, and sounds "for the purpose of displaying, distributing, and promoting your yahoo geocities site." yahoo also promised not to change that portion of the contract without the explicit agreement of its members.opponents had worried that yahoo could repackage or republish their web pages in any form, which the previous contract had allowed. "the new geocities [contract] addresses each of these concerns in a clear, positive, and concise manner which may well serve as a blueprint for similar terms of service agreements throughout the young internet community," said jim townsend, a boycott organizer.another boycott site simply said "we won!"the first modifications to the yahoo contract weren't good enough for many geocities users, who turned their pages gray in protest or simply abandoned the site.competitors were quick to take advantage of yahoo's misstep. warner bros. online began an advertising campaign friday, 2 july, to stress that, unlike yahoo, it has never claimed rights to what its acmecity members post on their sites. webjump.com, which says it has over 400,000 members, erected a protest site that proclaimed: "quite simply, when we say 'free' we mean it."under the old terms of service, geocities web page authors had to give yahoo a "royalty-free, perpetual, irrevocable, non-exclusive and fully sublicensable right and license to use, reproduce, modify, adapt, publish, translate, create derivative works from, distribute, perform and display such content" in any form or media.
